message: So, i've updated the class files to include a DatabaseHelper which allows the other classes to interact with the database through static methods
it then uses the database to determine if enough purchases have accrued to raise the customer to Gold level.
Each customer can get a list of all purchases in last 30 days or their lifetime through appropriate methods in Customer class.
I'll be creating a ReportGenerator class tonight that will generate reports for date and bestsellers, as well as handling/limiting preorders of desserts

The past few nights I've been working on the API (the approach mentioned in those articles I had linked to before), but I'm finishing it up right now and will start documenting how we should interact with it later tonight. (Since it's a web service, we won't shouldn't need to write / interact with MySQL directly in the Java code...we'll simply create HttpClients and send GET / POST / PUT / DELETE requests with JSON page bodies and the API will return the appropriate data/result). As an example, on the Java side we'd generate a JSON object that would look like this when added to the HttpClient and then POSTed to the appropriate URL for the API (and it'll create a new purchase record along with the associated items): http://pastebin.com/XY90DKRT
(hopefully all of the above makes sense...if you haven't worked with web services before it may sound a bit foreign)
I'm writing a whole bunch of queries on my end though ;-)

I had difficulty understangind the JSON requests in the article you posted.  I looked at this article http://php.about.com/od/phpwithmysql/fl/MySQL-and-Java.htm and understood it a bit better so that' show I implemented it.

Yup, that article is the normal way you'd expect to work with MySQL when working with Java...I thought it was a bit weird when I saw all of the web service examples when I searched for "android + mysql" the other week, but after a while it started to make sense since all of our modern applications are going to the web services route (and typically it's a lot easier to initiate an HTTP Request and get a response back from a server, rather than having to go through the overhead of establishing the database connection, querying the database, getting the results, and then closing the connection, particularly on a mobile device where the latency could be a bit higher). I'm pretty confident we'll be able to easily adapt what's there to use the web service instead)
ok
are you currently testing with a local MySQL database or setting up placeholders?
I set up placeholders as static variables in the Database class.
ok, I remember now you mentioned that a little while ago ;-)
Task 1 is done. still need to do task 2

Did we end up creating a list of desserts we wanted to have in the system? Towards the end of the API creation I was planning on populating the database with a few records (I already put in a few locations based on the neighborhoods around Atlanta :-)) but I couldn't remember us talking about the items we'd be selling
I don't think it's been determined.
I'll have my wife come up with a list ;-) (she's pretty into desserts, lol).

neither I nor my wife are coffee drinkers.
what about smoothies?
Well if we are getting wives into this I am out... :p

moms can be included too ;-)
LOL
@MuraliRaju  have you had a chance to look over the Customer/Item/Purchase/Coffee/Dessert/DB classes i wrote?

ofcourse they will -
I wish I had the patience you do when coding.
@OmarRamos should I make a new branch to avoid conflict.  You will have to merge it later thats why I am asking.

Were you guys going to be overlapping on what's being worked on at all? If not, then you should be able to continue working in the Deliverable3 branch, after pulling down the latest changes of course. If you do decide to make an additional branch we'll have to keep track of it (and rebase when it gets behind Deliverable3, so it might make things a little more complicated)
I didn't think we'd overlap much.  I was working more in pure java where Murali was doing the Android-specific code, I thought.
No plan to overlap - but you know how it goes.
I try to pull before pushing just to make sure i've got all changes.
I wont branch.
yup, so long as you do the pull beforehand you shouldn't run into much issue

which libraries are missing?
Date, BigDec etc in Customer for example.
In customer?
yah. fixing that.
usually eclipse gives me a heads up on that.
s'what I get for trusting my ide. better go back to vi.

Just finishing up the last bits of the API I can think of adding in at the moment...going to start deploying it on my server (it'll live over at http://coffeecart.orware.com/api once I get it up there) and writing the documentation so we can start using it ;-).

Just pushed up the initial version of the PHP Web Service API (still need to continue working on the documentation and deploying it). I'll add Chandra's Traceability document in just a bit after I get to review it real quick.
ok, afaik all the errors are fixed and patched.  I also fixed the rounding issue, so it should determine gold correctly.
@TonyPotter Are you using Customer class anywhere?  We should eliminate it.  Modify CoffeCart to use VIPCustomer instead of Customer.  Let me know if you are cool with this.

The customer class creates customer objects that determine if they are gold level by calling upon all their prior purchases.  It also provides a summary of all customer purchases for last 30 days and for lifetime, and Databasehelper uses the constructor to load customers from the database.
